messageBody:
Hi Alberto, good to see you again,

On 5/31/06, albsavoia <albsavoia@...> wrote:
>
> > I wear a green wrist band that says "Test First". It is a symbol of
> > my commitment to this minmium level of professional ethics. I WILL
> > TEST MY CODE.
>
> Bob,
>
> While I don't agree with you 100% on Test First being THE solution, or
> THE right approach in ALL cases, I am definitely more in your camp
> than not.


I agree. TDD is a powerful tool, but not as much as "simple testing". If a
developer prefers to write code first and tests then, that's perfectly fine
with me. The important point here is that this developer needs to agree
that writing tests is part of her job. At least to a certain extent.

When Roongko and I were at SunLabs, we headed a research project
> called ADL (Assertion Definition Language) that was close in spirit to
> test first: designers/developers would write the spec for the code
> before writing it. The spec included both syntax (e.g. the method
> signature) as well as semantics (what the method was supposed to do in
> terms of assertions (the A in ADL) - for example: if X < 0 throw
> InvalidArgumentException)).


I am not a big fan of design by contract (DBC) for the simple reason that it
is just not applicable in the real world, and if you look around, the only
illustrations of DBC that you see are for Money, BankAccount or Bowling
programs.

When you start solving real problems, this kind of assertions is either
super simple, and you can just use assertions in your code, or too
complicated to express with a DSL and you're then better off writing a test
for it. DBC sits in-between these two worlds and has never caught on for
that reason.

More details here <http://www.jroller.com/page/cbeust/20021213> (I wrote
this four years ago, but my points still stand).

Some developers, including some very good ones, are not wired to think test
> first. They could do it, but they would not be very effective at it -
> like asking a left-handed person to write with their write hand.


Good point. Another reason is that there are many situations where TDD is
simply not feasible. I've come across enough of these scenarios these past
years to start looking at TDD as something that is only *sometimes* useful.
If you're in a situation where you can use TDD, then by all means, go ahead
and do it: I certainly know how good it makes you feel. But keep in mind
you're lucky in the same way that somebody who can use Java to get their job
done is more lucky than someone forced to use COBOL :-)

Again, it's a matter of philosophy. If all the developers on your team
strongly feel that writing tests is part of their job, you will obtain
software of equal quality as you would from a team of TDD nuts.

--
Cédric
